div.head: Summary
div.p: In The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme, the Buddha, while spending the rainy season at the Bamboo Grove in Rājagṛha, teaches his saṅgha of śrāvakas that the Buddha is supreme among all beings, the Dharma of being free of attachment is supreme among all dharmas, and the Saṅgha is supreme among all communities and groups. In this way, the sūtra gives a variation on the classic formulation of the Three Jewels.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This sūtra was translated by Giuliano Proença, who also prepared the introduction, glossary, and notes. The English translation and ancillary materials were proofread by Daniela Espíndola. Thanks to Karin Kerb for making otherwise unavailable bibliographical material accessible to us.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme (Agra­prajñapti­sūtra, Toh 305) is a short discourse set in the Bamboo Grove at Rājagṛha, in which the Buddha designates three things as supreme: the Buddha as supreme among all beings, the dharma of being free of attachment as supreme among all dharmas, and the Saṅgha as supreme among all communities and groups. In this way, The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme provides a variation on the theme of the Three Jewels. The Buddha also states that the reward of being well disposed toward these three things is rebirth as a god or as a human.

Little is known about the history of The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme as an independent text in India, but the existence of parallel texts in the Pali and Chinese canons testifies to its antiquity. The Pali canon emerged in written form around the first century bce. The oldest Chinese parallel for this text is included in the Ekottarikāgama (Taishō 125). It was translated into Chinese in 384 ce. The closest Pali parallel is the Aggappasādasutta (Iti 90), while the Aggappasādasutta (AN 4.34) and the Cundīsutta (AN 5.32) are also closely related. For online links to all three Pali texts along with English translations, see the Bibliography. In the Aggappasādasutta (Iti 90), these same three things are proclaimed as supreme, using similar language, and they are said therein to be the objects of the supreme kinds of confidence, faith, or favorable disposition (Pali aggappasāda), as suggested by its title. The Pali also includes several more words describing the referent of the Dharma as supreme, which in turn highlights semantic flexibility of the word Dharma/dharma as both teaching and phenomenon.

The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme may have had a significant status in early Buddhist Central Asia, since we find Sanskrit fragments of the sūtra, and its commentaries in a variety of manuscripts unearthed in present-day Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, China. In addition to an unpublished fragment in the Hoernle Collection, British Library, Hoernle 149.140. a fragment in the Pelliot Collection was published by Bernard Pauly. Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Pelliot Sanskrit: petit fragment 83. Pauly (1960, pp. 519–24) provides a transcription of the fragment and reproduces a passage from Speyer’s edition of the Avadānaśataka, which is supplemented with notes detailing variant readings of the fragment. This latter fragment contains the passage concerning the designation of the Buddha as supreme and is only slightly different from the quotations of this sūtra found in the Sanskrit text of the Avadānaśataka.

The Turfan Collection also holds two fragments from commentaries on The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme: a Sanskrit fragment partially edited by Ernst Waldschmidt that includes the colophon, Oriental Department of the State Library at Berlin, SHT 24f. See Waldschmidt (1965), pp. 16–17, n. 24. and an Old Turkish and Sanskrit bilingual fragment containing the beginning of a commentary on the sūtra. Türkische Turfan-Text VIII H. See von Gabain (1954), pp. 54–56. Again, the quotations found in these closely match those found in the Avadānaśataka, a Sanskrit anthology of avadānas that quotes The S ūtra on the Designations as Supreme almost in its entirety, in two different passages (stories 9 and 57). The Tibetan translation of the Avadānaśataka, which also contains these extensive quotations, is included in the Kangyur (Toh 343), In the ninth story, there is no setting or conclusion given for The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme, although it is referred to as a sūtra: bhagavān idaṃ sūtraṃ bhāṣate sma. In that version, the Buddha preaches the sūtra to brahmins and householders. See Speyer (1902–06), pp. 49–50. In the fifty-seventh story, only the setting is omitted, and the Buddha preaches it to monks, as found here in The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme. See Speyer (1902–6), pp. 329–30. and the wording in these quotations is almost identical to the present sūtra. An abridged form of the Agra­prajñapti­sūtra is also quoted in the Divyāvadāna For a Sanskrit edition, see Vaidya (1959), p. 95, and for an English translation, see Rotman (2008), p. 268. as well as in the Great Upholder of the Secret Mantra (Toh 563, 1.45–1.47). The quotation in the Great Upholder of the Secret Mantra, one of the Pañcarakṣā, suggests the sūtra was considered to have a protective function. This would be in line with the Pañcarakṣā being seen as protective texts (Hartmann and Maue,1996, p. 149, n. 9).

Two parallels of the sūtra are extant in the Chinese Tripitaka: the closest parallel is found as part of the Ekottarikāgama (Zeng yi a han jing 增壹阿含經, Taishō 125). Ekottarikāgama 21.1 (di yi de 第一徳). An English translation of this text from Chinese by Thích Huyên-Vi, Sara Boin-Webb, and Bhikkhu Pāsādika is available at SuttaCentral with the title Highest Faith . Current scholarly consensus holds that the Chinese translation of the Ekottarikāgama was, for the most part, completed by Zhu Fonian (竺佛念) in 384 ce. See Bhikkhu Anālayo (2016), p. 1. The discourse in this text has a different setting, and unlike Toh 305, is presented in similes and verses. Also parallel are the three sūtras (nos. 902–904) of the Saṃyuktāgama (Za a han jing 雜阿含經, Taishō 99), which likewise designate each of the three designations in turn as supreme. As in the Agra­prajñapti­sūtra, the setting in all three is the Bamboo Grove at Rājagṛha. The Saṃyuktāgama was translated into Chinese between 435 and 443 ce by Guṇabhadra (394–468) and Baoyun 寶雲 (376–449) in Jiankang (today’s Nanjing). See Bingenheimer (2011), p. 1.

The translators of The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme into Tibetan remain unidentified and the sūtra is not listed in any catalogs of the Tibetan imperial period. It seems likely that it was translated from Sanskrit. The striking similarity between the Tibetan of The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme (Toh 305) and its citation in the Tibetan translation of the Avadānaśataka (Toh 343) suggests that these translations were unlikely to have been made independently of one another. The colophon of the Tibetan Avadānaśataka (Toh 343) states that it was translated by the scholars Jinamitra and Devacandra who were active in Tibet in the early ninth century. By extension therefore, the Tibetan translation of the Agra­prajñapti­sūtra may also be substantively dated to the early ninth century.

The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme is only found as an independent text in the Sūtra section of Kangyurs of the Tshalpa line, the Lhasa and Narthang Kangyurs, and in the Tholing Collection from Western Tibet. The Tibetan title of the text is the same in all Kangyurs included in the Pedurma, mchog tu gdags pa’i mdo, while the Tholing Collection has ’phags pa mchog tu gdags pa’i mdo. For further information, see Resources for Kanjur and Tenjur Studies at Universität Wein (last accessed 30 May 2023). Versions such as the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, Narthang, and Choné, do not present the name of the text at the beginning. The Sanskrit title of the sūtra is missing in all versions. Nevertheless, the colophon of the abovementioned fragmentary Sanskrit commentary clearly refers to the sūtra using the title Agra­prajñapti­sūtra. Although the colophon is fragmentary, it begins as follows: agra­prajñapti­sūtrasyopadeśaḥ…, “instructions on The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme…” See Waldschmidt (1965), p. 16.

This English translation is based on the Degé Kangyur print of Toh 305, in consultation with the Comparative Edition (dpe bsdur ma) and Pauly’s edition of the Sanskrit fragment. We also compared the Tibetan text line by line with the quotations from the sūtra in the Avadānaśataka in both Sanskrit Speyer (1902–6) edited the Sanskrit text of the Avadānaśataka based on four different Nepalese manuscripts. Manuscript B in Nepalese script, dated to 1645, is the common source for the other three. Vaidya (1958) published another edition based on Speyer’s. and Tibetan (Toh 343). The translation also benefited from Léon Feer’s early French translation of the Avadānaśataka
Feer’s translation (1891) predates Speyer’s edition and is based on a single Nepalese manuscript. and Naomi Appleton’s more recent partial English translation of the same. Naomi Appleton (2020) translates the first four sections of the Avadānaśataka, with a commentary that reflects the advances of modern scholarship in the field.

div.head: The Translation
The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme

div.p: Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Bhagavān, together with a saṅgha of śrāvakas, was staying at Kalandakanivāsa in the Bamboo Grove at Rājagṛha, observing the pledge to stay in retreat during the rains. Then the Bhagavān spoke to the monks: The quotation from the Agraprajñapti in the Avadānaśataka (Avś), and in its Tibetan translation (Toh 343) begins with this sentence.

“Monks, the designations as supreme are three. Reading with KY, K, C, U and H: dge slong dag ’di gsum ni mchog tu gdags pa yin te, and Avś tisra imā bhikṣavo ’graprajñaptayaḥ. D here has the corrupt reading na in place of ni. What are the three? They are the designation of the Buddha as supreme, the designation of the Dharma as supreme, and the designation of the Saṅgha as supreme.

“In this regard, The phrase “in this regard” (Tib. de la) is absent in Avś and in Toh 343. what is the designation of the Buddha as supreme? It is declared that among all beings—those without legs, with two legs, with four legs, The phrase “beings with four legs” is absent in Avś, though present in Frgm and in Toh 343. or with many legs; those with form or without form; those with perception, without perception, or neither with perception nor without perception This refers to the category of beings abiding in the fourth and highest level of the formless realm. These are either the gods that abide there or persons who have reached this state through meditative equipoise. This state is also referred to as the “peak of existence” (Skt. bhavāgra; Tib. srid rtse) and is situated at the apex of saṃsāra. The beings there do not experience perceptions and yet cannot be said to be without perceptions.—the tathāgata, the arhat, the completely perfect Buddha The phrase “the arhat, the completely perfect Buddha” is absent in Frgm. is supreme. Those who are well disposed toward the Buddha are well disposed toward the supreme. For those who are well disposed toward the supreme, supreme ripening alone may be expected, either as gods among gods, or humans among humans. This is called the designation of the Buddha as supreme. Frgm reads instead iyaṃ prathamā agraprajñaptiḥ, “This is the first designation as supreme.”

“What is the designation of the Dharma as supreme? It is declared that among all dharmas, conditioned or unconditioned, the dharma of being free from attachment is supreme. Alternatively, this may be rendered “dispassion (i.e., being free of attachment) is the supreme dharma.” Those who are well disposed toward the Dharma are well disposed toward the supreme. For those who are well disposed toward the supreme, supreme ripening alone may be expected, either as gods among gods, or humans among humans. This is called the designation of the Dharma as supreme.

“What is the designation of the Saṅgha as supreme? It is declared that among all assemblies, gatherings, crowds, and retinues, the Saṅgha of śrāvakas of the tathāgata, the arhat, the completely perfect Buddha The phrase “the arhat, the completely perfect Buddha” is absent in Avś and its Tibetan translation (Toh 343). is supreme. Those who are well disposed toward the Saṅgha are well disposed toward the supreme. For those who are well disposed toward the supreme, supreme ripening alone may be expected, either as gods among gods, or humans among humans. This is called the designation of the Saṅgha as supreme.”
After the Bhagavān had spoken thus, the monks rejoiced and praised his words.
div.trailer: Thus ends “The Sūtra on the Designations as Supreme.”

gloss.term: The assertion that a person or thing is the best of its kind. Here the Buddha is designated as supreme among all beings, the dharma of being free of attachment as supreme among all dharmas, and the Saṅgha as supreme among all communities and groups.

The Indic term buddha is used in Buddhism as an epithet for fully awakened beings in general and, more specifically, often refers to the historical buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama, also known as the Buddha Śākyamuni. The term buddha is the past participle of the Sanskrit root budh, meaning “to awaken,” “to understand,” or “to become aware.” Sometimes also translated here as “awakened one.”

[adapted from Toh 113] A term that predates Buddhism, Dharma/dharma has a wide range of meanings and usages in Buddhist texts depending on context:When rendered as the Dharma, it refers in toto to the teaching of the Buddha Śākyamuni and other buddhas, preached by their followers, and transmitted in the form of scripture; and, in addition, the nature of reality itself, the referent of the Buddha’s teaching, and also what is realized through it. When rendered as dharma or dharmas, it can refer variously to the different teachings given by the Buddha Śākyamuni, other buddhas, and their followers; the trainings enjoined in those teachings; the positive qualities acquired through applying those trainings; mental phenomena in general; or phenomena in general or their characteristics. Often in Buddhist literature, and certainly in this sūtra, there is a play on the multiple interlinked senses of this term.
The Sanskrit term means either “favorably disposed towards” or “having faith in.” The Tibetan term means “highly appreciating.”
Other possible translations as an adjective would include “best”, “first” or “foremost.” Or as a noun, “best of its kind” or “excellence.”
yang dag par rdzogs pa’i sangs rgyas
The result or maturation of karmic actions and the manifestation of their effects.

When referring to phenomena or the constituents of experience, saṃskṛta usually means “conditioned.” But it can also mean “refined,” “adorned,” “ornamented,” “polished.” It seems that the text is here playing on the multivalence of the term in combination with the multivalence of the term “dharma.”

When referring to phenomena or constituents of experience, asaṃskṛta usually means “unconditioned.” But it can also mean “unrefined,” “unadorned,” “unpolished.” It seems that the text is here playing on the multivalence of the term in combination with the multivalence of the term “dharma.”

The famous Bamboo Grove in Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha, and as such, was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist community during the time of the Buddha.
bya ka lan da ka gnas pa

Literally “the dwelling place of kalandakas.” A location within the Bamboo Grove where the Buddha stayed. The alternative Sanskrit Kalandakanivāpa means “where food offerings are made to kalandakas.” It is said that the place was given its name by King Bimbisāra after he was rescued from a snake attack there. Pali sources suggest he was saved by the squawking of many kalandaka or flying squirrels. In Tibetan translation these were called “kalandaka birds” (bya).
